prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: A Spectroscopic Redshift for MACS1149-JD: Tuning 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these observations is to measure the far-IR dust emission and to search for the [OIII]88.56 line in the z~9.7 candidate MACS1149-JD

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Proposed Targets: To maximize the likelihood of success, we propose to target the brightest z~10 candidate currently known and also the z~10 candidate with the most accurate redshift. Other candidates like the bright Oesch et al. (2013) z~10 candidates over the CANDELS-North field or the Coe et al. (2013) z=10.8 candidate are not observable with ALMA.
Proposed ALMA Band: To measure a redshift for the Zheng et al. (2013) z=9.7 candidate, it will be necessary to detect a strong emission line from the source. Unfortunately, the [CII] line is not available for observation lying at 177 GHz in the unavailable ALMA band 5. Other strong lines include [OI]63.18 at 442 GHz (see Figure 2), but this lies in part of the ALMA band 8 spectral window where the atmospheric transmission is low. The best option is therefore the strong [OIII]88.36 line at 317 GHz. Over most of the redshift window where the candidate is expected to lie (z=9.4-10.0), the [OIII]88.36 line could be easily observed. The only problematic redshift for the source would be in the range z=9.35-9.5, where the [OIII]88.36 line would fall on top of a strong water absorption line.
Required Integration Time: Our integration time requirements are driven by the prospect of detecting the [OIII]88.36 line in the MACS1149-JD source (Zheng+2012). We compute the required integration time based on the observed UV luminosity to calculate the equivalent star formation rate. For MACS1149-JD, we compute an equivalent SFR of 30 Msolar/year. Then, relying on the SFR-[CII] relation found by de Looze+2011, we can estimate the approximate luminosity of our target in the [CII] line to be 2 x 1042 erg/s. Taking advantage of the local calibration sample of Spinoglio+2012 and the relationship between the bolometric luminosities and line luminosities, we convert this luminosity into the equivalent luminosity for the [OIII]88.36 line, which is 1 x 1042 erg/s. Assuming a FWHM for the line of 50 km/s (similar to what Carilli+2013 find for [CII] in a z~4.7 galaxy and as Vallini+2013 predict from their models), we estimate a line width of 0.05 GHz for the [OIII]88.36 line. For the estimated luminosity, this translates to a flux density of 1.9 mJy for the [OIII]88.36 line.
Using the ALMA sensitivity calculator, we estimate to detect this line at 5 sigma, we would require ~47 minutes of integration time at most probable redshifts (with the exception of the short redshift range z=9.35-9.5). We propose to use four tunings on the source, since it allows us to cover the entire redshift range z = 9.25 to z=10.1. Our photometric redshift estimate suggests the source should lie in this redshift range with >95% probability.
There are several arguments for supposing that the actual flux in the [OIII]88.36 line may be double what we estimated above and therefore our time estimates may have been very conservative. First of all, the ratio of [OIII]88.36 to [CII]157.7 flux is often found to be much higher in low-mass, low-metallicity galaxies than it is in galaxies in the nearby universe (Madden+2012; see also Cormier+2012). Second, it is now quite well established that rest-frame optical [OIII]5007 emission is much more prevalent in lower metallicity, z>3 galaxies than it is locally (Schenker+2013; Smit+2013; Labbe+2013; Finkelstein+2013). Finally, new simulation results from Inoue+2013 predict the [OIII]88.36 fluxes in z~9 galaxy candidates at this luminosity to be 3 mJy.
Our assumption of a flux density of 1.9 mJy for the [OIII]88.36 line is therefore a conservative lower limit and we can thus expect to be able to detect the line at very high confidence (at >5 sigma, and up to 8 sigma).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: A Spectroscopic Redshift for MACS1149-JD: Tuning 4

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Characterizing the properties of galaxies forming at the earliest epochs of the universe remains one of the most important goals of ALMA. Perhaps our best prospect for realizing this goal is by targetting the brightest z>9 galaxies identified on the sky. Arguably, the best candidate for doing so is the robust z~9.7 galaxy MACS1149-JD our team has identified behind MACSJ1149. With a deep 3-hour integration in ALMA band 7, we have the prospect of confirming its redshift through the detection of the [OIII]88.36 line, which would make this galaxy the highest-redshift spectroscopically- confirmed galaxy to date. We expect a S/N from 5 to 10 for our proposed integration time. The detection of an [OIII] line in this galaxy would open the door both to the follow-up of other lines within this galaxy and to similar searches for this line in other z>8 galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Johns Hopkins University
University of California Observatories/Lick Observatory, California at Santa Cruz, University of
European Space Research and Technology Center (ESTEC), European Space Agency (ESA)
